attributes.title: Amanda Herzig's Final Project
attributes.description: The participants will be in a 2x2 factorial designed experiment on the influence of the facts of binge drinking and public and private environments. They were randomly assigned in a survey.

q2.value: Participants who are given the binge drinking fact with higher numbers of drinks are more likely to drink more in public and private environments.  In contrast to the participants who are given the binge drinking fact with a lower number of drinks in public settings.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2 (facts of binge drinking) x 2 (public or private environment) design

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: I am posting a link to social media for participants to follow to fill out my survey. The survey includes demographics, a measure of a school, questions about their college (if in college), and one between variables and one within variables to determine the influence of binge drinking facts and environment plays a role in how much college students drink. Participants will be assigned into groups by choosing their favorite color of the rainbow.

question.value: Ideally, I will I would like to have around 80-100 participants total to complete this survey.

q11.value: My professor said to at least have 50 per cell of my factorial design for my between-variable group.

q13.value: I plan to stop collecting dating until I have 50 for each cell.

question.value:
I have manipulated facts about drinking for two-levels. First,  Binge drinking is when men who consumed five or more drinks, or women who consumed four or more, on one occasion during the previous two weeks. Second,  Binge drinking is when men who consumed eight or more drinks, or women who consumed seven or more, on one occasion during the previous two weeks.

The other independent variable I manipulated was the environment. The two levels were either being private or public. One example private environment was
"My family is out to an Italian dinner and we are all drinking together. I will have  ..".  An example of a public environment was "I am out to a college party with friends at a frat house, and there is a keg. I will have".

IV-  Fact about binge drinking (between) 
IV- Public and Private Environment (within) 
DV- the number of drinks the participant would consume
I plan to add my variables for the mean for questions involving private environments and questions requiring public environments.

ANOVA, to test for an interaction between public environments and the higher number of drinks for the fact about binge drinking and private environments and a lower number of drinks for the fact about the binge drinking.

attributes.title: Scoping review protocol: Virtual reality towards myoelectric prosthesis training and assessment in the upper-limb amputee
attributes.description: Protocol for a systematic scoping review titled: Virtual reality towards myoelectric prosthesis training and assessment in the upper-limb amputee

q1.value: Hugo Ghazi, Marie Carpentier, Alexis Lheureux, Renaud Ronsse

q2.value: Use of virtual reality towards myoelectric prosthesis training and assessment in the upper-limb amputee.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Protocol for a Systematic Scoping review

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Inclusion criteria:
-	Population: Patients with amputation/disarticulation/limb loss in the upper limb and able-bodied subjects.
-	Concept: Development and/or testing of a virtual reality system towards upper limb prosthesis training and/or assessment.
-	Context: Any country and any stage of amputation. 
-	Study design: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), non-RCTs, before-after studies with or without control group, interrupted time series (ITS), cohort studies, case control studies, cases series, case reports, feasibility studies, design and development studies (D&D), conference paper, systematic reviews, literature reviews and meta-analyses.
- 	Languages: English and French.
- 	Years considered: Any year.

Exclusion criteria:
-	Population: Non-human (animal) and patient with a non-limb amputation (e.g: breast amputation, genitals amputation, ear amputation, nose amputation) or lower limb amputation.
-	Concept: Development and/or testing of a virtual reality system towards training of a pattern recognition-based myoelectric controller.
-	Study design: Training procedures or protocols without testing.
-	Availability: Full-text not accessible.
-	Languages: Full-text not available in French/English.

q11.value: 2018 studies were found and will be reviewed.

attributes.title: Disgust Sensitivity across Menstrual Cycle
attributes.description: This study aimed to investigate fluctuations in disgust sensitivity across different stages of the menstrual cycle.

q2.value: Busra Bahar Balci, Sena Tekçe, Adelina Sanem Akçay, Burcu Tekeş

q3.value: Women have an evolutionary tendency to avoid risk of conception in order to protect themselves and their future offsprings. As an evolved adaptive mechanism, disgust has a function to protect organism from  threats such as contagious diseases. Related literature suggest that women experience more disgust when their progesterone levels increase (Fleischman and Fessler, 2011). Thus, in this study, we will investigate fluctuations in disgust sensitivity across different stages of the menstrual cycle (early follicular and mid-luteal phase). Therefore, we decided to compare disgust sensitivity levels between the early follicular and mid-luteal phase within subjects.

q4.value: It is expected that disgust sensitivity will be higher in the mid-luteal phase, than in the early follicular phase.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Within-subject design
1. IV (Menstrual cycle, 2 levels: early-follicular and mid-luteal)
2. IV (Images, 2 levels: disgust related and neutral images) 
1. DV (Disgust measures, 1 level: Self-Report (Likert type rating scale will be used))

Covariant: disgust sensitivity scale scores

q9.value: It will be conducted a counterbalanced measure design. Some participants will participate in the early follicular phase first, and the others will participate in the mid-luteal phase first. Also, the images will be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants: Female undergraduate students will take part in each experimental condition. Students will see the online announcement and signed, will accept volunteers to participate in research. The participant will be rewarded with 5 points for their participation. For students who are not suitable for the requirements, the additional activity will be provided for the same amount (5 points). Participants’ age estimated to be between 18-25 years. Participants should have a normal menstrual cycle, which should be changed between 21 to 35 days. Participants should not use any medicine that can affect their hormone levels (e.g. birth control pill).

q13.value: A power analysis with GPower (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, and Buchner, 2007) recommended 84 participants as the sample size to detect interested effect size of .20 by 95% power and .05 alpha value.  We will attempt to recruit up to 100 (approximately), assuming that some participants will not attend the second session.

q14.value: A power analysis with GPower (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, and Buchner, 2007) recommended 84 participants as sample size to detect an interested effect size of .20 by 95% power and .05 alpha value.  We will attempt to recruit up to 100 (approximately), assuming that some participants will not attend the second session.

q15.value: We aim to stop when we reached at 84 participants (approximately) in total.

question.value: Participants' disgust level will be triggered by showing them disgust related images via Qualtrics. In addition to these images, they will see neutral images, too. To see if the disgust images used in the phases of the menstrual cycle differ, we asked female participants to evaluate the disgust levels of the images.

Images:  Necessary visual materials are sent by International Affective Picture System (IAPS). IAPS aims to provide “emotionally-evocative, internationally-accessible, color photographs” that are categorized semantically (Lang, Bradleya and Cuthbert, 2008). IAPS kindly asks for
not showing the images to anyone except for participants, images cannot be shared on any
platform of media. Selected disgust-related images did not differ in terms of the strength of the image. A pilot study was conducted with 16 participants via Qualtrics and asked them to evaluate their disgust levels on disgust-related images. A paired sample t-test result showed that there was no significant difference between disgust related images which are aimed to use in follicular and luteal conditions. Related data was presented as an attachment. 
 
Demographic Information Form: Participants will be asked about their demographic characteristics such as age. Also, they will be asked to answer some questions about their menstrual cycle (whether their cycles are regular, if regular, how many days their cycle is, whether they use an application that follows their cycles, if they do not use, informing them that they should use, date of their last cycle).

Self Report Disgust: Participants will indicate their level of disgust on a scale of 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely disgusting). 

Disgust Sensitivity Scale-Revised Form (DS-R): The Disgust Sensitivity Scale was developed by Haidt, McCauley, and Rozin (1994) to evaluate differences among individuals in disgust sensitivity, it was revised by Olatunji, Sawchuk, de Jong and Lohr (2007), and lastly by Olatunji, Haidt, McKay, and David (2008). The Turkish version of the final revised form, consisting of 5 items of Likert type and 27 items, was adapted by İnözü and Eremsoy in 2013. The Disgust Sensitivity Scale has Cronbach’s alpha internal consistency value as .87 for the total scale and value ranged between .75 to .64 for the subscales.

We are going to calculate a mean score for Disgust Sensitivity Scale-Revised Form (DS-R).
Additionally, the self-reported disgust answers to the images as well as control (neutral) images will be calculated as mean scores.

A two-way repeated ANCOVA will be performed with self-report disgust level as the dependent variable, two different types of images (disgust related and neutral images) and two different phases of the menstrual cycle (follicular and luteal) as the independent variables. 
Disgust sensitivity level will be covariant.

q20.value:
- "Disgust sensitivity scale": Recoded items are 1, 6 and 10. Filler items are 12 and 16.
- The menstrual cycle phases will be calculated by researchers.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANCOVA and the post hoc test results.

q22.value: Participants who do not answer 0 or 1 to item 16 ("You see a person eating an apple with a knife and fork."), 3 or 4 to item 12 ("I would rather eat a piece of fruit than a piece of paper ") will not be included in the data because the items (filler items) marked otherwise indicate that the participants filled the questionnaire randomly.

q23.value: If a subject will not attend both conditions, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q25.value:

University of Florida, Gainesville, FL.

attributes.title: Wishful Seeing Research Project
attributes.description: This is our preregistration to conduct research and further study the phenomena of wishful seeing.

q1.value: Wishful Seeing and Distance Perception in College Students

q2.value: Caroline Crowley, Destiny Ramsey, Conner Cheramie, Christopher Hart

q4.value: We hypothesize that objects possessing a high desirability are perceived as being closer than objects of less desirability. We predict the participants in our study will view more desirable objects as being physically closer to them.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
For our study, we propose to conduct five separate experiments to further analyze the phenomena of wishful seeing in the undergraduate population at Louisiana State University. 

In the first study, 90 undergraduate students at Louisiana State University (LSU) will be instructed to estimate their distance between their position and a bottle of water. The desirability of the water will be manipulated to either be inducing or quenching to the participants thirst. Participants with higher thirst are expected to perceive the water bottle as closer in perception than participants who are not thirsty.This is a between subjects design with 2 factors: thirsty--ate pretzels; quenched--drank as much water as they wanted. With one level: judged distance to a bottle of water. 

Study 2a will measure desirability based on social values. Our ideal sample will consist of about 123 LSU students that will either receive candy or receive candy and a chance to win a $100 bill. We predict that the more desirable object, the $100 bill, will be perceived as being physically closer to the viewer than the candy. This is a between subjects design with 2 factors--receiving candy or receiving candy and a chance to win a $100 bill. Along with 2 levels--the participants judged how far they were away from the bill and they completed a creativity test as a measure of mood to be associated with creativity and randomness of responses. 

In study 2b, about 90 LSU students will take a survey that assesses sense of humor that will be graded in their presence. Participants will be randomly assigned to positive and negative feedback conditions. After being told if they have a “below average” or “above average” sense of humor, the participants will then be instructed to provide an estimate of how far away their test is. We predict that those who received positive feedback about their sense of humor will perceive their test as being more desirable and physically closer to the viewer. This is a between subjects design with 2 factors: Positive or negative feedback on their sense of humor. With 1 level: judged how far away their humor test was. 

Study 3a uses interaction with objects by having 40 LSU students complete a beanbag toss. The participants will be instructed to toss a bean bag towards a Visa gift card adhered to the floor. Some participants will be exposed to the desired object and know the gift card has a value of $25.Other participants will be exposed to the less desirable object and know the gift card has a value of $0. The prediction of this study is that participants will underthrow the beanbag towards the desired object as it will possibly be perceived to be closer. This is a between subjects design with 2 factors: Gift card having value or the gift card having no value. With 1 level: tossing the bean bag as close as you can to the gift card. 

In study 3b, 52 LSU students will be asked to match their distance from chocolate (desirable) and dog feces (less desirable) to the distance between the two pieces of tape on the wall. We predict that the participants will stand further from the chocolate because they see it as closer than the dog feces. This is a between-subjects design and with 2 factors: seeing chocolate and dog feces on a table and the one 1 level is to walk towards the object until the distance between them and the object is the same as the distance between the tape on the wall.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will use convenience sampling and randomly select from the population of LSU Psychology major classes. We will reach out to psychology professors and add our experiment to SONA online, which is a way students can gain extra credit by participating in experiments. We plan on carrying out this study for about two months to work with student schedules and acquire our desired sample sizes.

q13.value: In this study, there will be a total of 5 experiments conducted. For the first study, we will use 90 participants. For the second study, we are aiming to have around 123 participants and for the third study we would like 90 participants. For the fourth study, we hope to use 40 participants, and about 52 participants will be used for the fifth study. Our total target sample size will be around 395 participants. We will attempt to recruit/select up 420 participants assuming not all will complete the task.

question.value: Perception, distance, desirability, thirst

For our first study, we will analyze data collected from Likert scale ratings that measure the water bottle’s desirability. We will also look at how the participants’s thirst and quench levels differed prior to the experiment. As for study 2a, we will examine the distance estimates given by the participants. In study 2b, we will look at the survey’s amount of desirability based on Likert scale ratings. To do this, we will also examine the distance estimates provided by our participants. For study 3a, we will inspect how the participants perceived the gift card based on how they throw the beanbag in each condition. Lastly, for study 3b, we will look at perceptions of distance in each condition.

For the second study, we are aiming to have around 123 participants and for the third study we would like 90 participants. For the fourth study, we hope to use 40 participants, and about 52 participants will be used for the fifth study. Our total target sample size will be around 395 participants. We will attempt to recruit/select up 420 participants assuming not all will complete the task.
registration_responses.q8.question:
For our study, we propose to conduct five separate experiments to further analyze the phenomena of wishful seeing in the undergraduate population at Louisiana State University. 

In the first study, 90 undergraduate students at Louisiana State University (LSU) will be instructed to estimate their distance between their position and a bottle of water. The desirability of the water will be manipulated to either be inducing or quenching to the participants thirst. Participants with higher thirst are expected to perceive the water bottle as closer in perception than participants who are not thirsty.This is a between subjects design with 2 factors: thirsty--ate pretzels; quenched--drank as much water as they wanted. With one level: judged distance to a bottle of water. 

Study 2a will measure desirability based on social values. Our ideal sample will consist of about 123 LSU students that will either receive candy or receive candy and a chance to win a $100 bill. We predict that the more desirable object, the $100 bill, will be perceived as being physically closer to the viewer than the candy. This is a between subjects design with 2 factors--receiving candy or receiving candy and a chance to win a $100 bill. Along with 2 levels--the participants judged how far they were away from the bill and they completed a creativity test as a measure of mood to be associated with creativity and randomness of responses. 

In study 2b, about 90 LSU students will take a survey that assesses sense of humor that will be graded in their presence. Participants will be randomly assigned to positive and negative feedback conditions. After being told if they have a “below average” or “above average” sense of humor, the participants will then be instructed to provide an estimate of how far away their test is. We predict that those who received positive feedback about their sense of humor will perceive their test as being more desirable and physically closer to the viewer. This is a between subjects design with 2 factors: Positive or negative feedback on their sense of humor. With 1 level: judged how far away their humor test was. 

Study 3a uses interaction with objects by having 40 LSU students complete a beanbag toss. The participants will be instructed to toss a bean bag towards a Visa gift card adhered to the floor. Some participants will be exposed to the desired object and know the gift card has a value of $25.Other participants will be exposed to the less desirable object and know the gift card has a value of $0. The prediction of this study is that participants will underthrow the beanbag towards the desired object as it will possibly be perceived to be closer. This is a between subjects design with 2 factors: Gift card having value or the gift card having no value. With 1 level: tossing the bean bag as close as you can to the gift card. 

In study 3b, 52 LSU students will be asked to match their distance from chocolate (desirable) and dog feces (less desirable) to the distance between the two pieces of tape on the wall. We predict that the participants will stand further from the chocolate because they see it as closer than the dog feces. This is a between-subjects design and with 2 factors: seeing chocolate and dog feces on a table and the one 1 level is to walk towards the object until the distance between them and the object is the same as the distance between the tape on the wall.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will use convenience sampling and randomly select from the population of LSU Psychology major classes. We will reach out to psychology professors and add our experiment to SONA online, which is a way students can gain extra credit by participating in experiments. We plan on carrying out this study for about two months to work with student schedules and acquire our desired sample sizes.
registration_responses.q17.question: Perception, distance, desirability, thirst
registration_responses.q19.question: For our first study, we will analyze data collected from Likert scale ratings that measure the water bottle’s desirability. We will also look at how the participants’s thirst and quench levels differed prior to the experiment. As for study 2a, we will examine the distance estimates given by the participants. In study 2b, we will look at the survey’s amount of desirability based on Likert scale ratings. To do this, we will also examine the distance estimates provided by our participants. For study 3a, we will inspect how the participants perceived the gift card based on how they throw the beanbag in each condition. Lastly, for study 3b, we will look at perceptions of distance in each condition.

attributes.title: PSYC 2017
attributes.description: We are testing the relationships between political ideology and bullshit receptivity, religiousness and political ideology, and religiousness and bullshit receptivity.

q2.value: Madison LeBlanc, Kristen Allen, Sophie Hobbs, victoria cano, Megan Dupuy

q4.value:
Sophie Hobbs Hypothesis: I hypothesize that within this study, people who are on the political right of the political spectrum will be more susceptible to bullshit than to those on the left
Madison LeBlanc: My main hypothesis is that there will be a significant correlation between socially conservative views and the tendency to believe fake news.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It is a correlational study design where we are testing the relationships between political ideology and bullshit receptivity, religiousness and political ideology, and religiousness and bullshit receptivity.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk and paid $1 for agreeing to complete the survey.  The participant pool will only consist of English-speaking residents of the United States.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200, but we will attempt to recruit up to 250 in case all of the participants do not complete the survey.

question.value: The variables we are measuring are receptivity to bullshit, religiousness, and political belief. We will use the Erlandsson et al. measure of political ideology. We will use the Pennycook Bullshit sensitivity measure, which includes measures of pseudo-profound bullshit and fake news, and we will use the Bardis Religion Scale.

We are doing 3 separate Pearson correlations. The first will determine the correlation between political ideology and bullshit receptivity. The second will correlate religiosity and political ideology, and the third will correlate religiosity and bullshit receptivity.

q23.value: If any surveys are not fully completed, we will exclude their data and omit them from the sample.

attributes.title: In-class laptop usage
attributes.description: I will run a project to determine the effectiveness of computers in the classroom.

q1.value: Electronic Devices Affect on Learning and Memory

q2.value: Maggie Butler, Cody Capps, Erin Fortier

q3.value: In the past, there's been strong evidence suggesting undesired effects from laptop use in the classroom. My study will focus on how using electronics in the classroom or while studying inhibits the efficiency of learning and memory as opposed to writing your own notes.

q4.value: Self-regulating behaviors of students who manage their electronic usage in the classroom will perform better on cognition and memory tasks. The predictions include: a) better performance for participants with handwritten notes as opposed to electronic devices due to less verbatim overlap b) better performance for older participants due to increased consolidated learning paired with acceptable hypercorrection abilities  c) higher performance for efficacious students compared to less self-regulating students when posed with electronic device usage in the classroom.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: While using control groups, the research will be a between-subjects ANOVA with 1 D.V. (academic performance over the span of a year) with 5 I.V. (age, note-taking medium, amount of electronic device usage, self-regulating behaviors, and content difficulty). The study plans to differentiate results between groups to acquire collective, holistic results.

q9.value: The experiment will use stratified sampling to accurately represent the population by accommodating for subcategories and calculating proportions. A list will be made for each variable (age, self-regulating behaviors, electronic device use, etc.) For example, in the age category, people 35+ y/o make up 55% while people younger than 35 make up 45% of the population, so my study will involve 55% people 35 or older and 45% below 35 y/o. Additionally, each of the 5 groups will have 100 participants for a total of 500. The groups will be taken from Louisiana State University ranging from 18-50 years old, and, as an incentive, will be payed $15 for participating.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: I will used a stratified sampling method at LSU that includes people ranging from 18-50 years old. Participants must not suffer from any cognitive disabilities and must be available for up to a year of research. Participants will receive compensation, $15, for participating in the experiment and $30 for each class taught. There will be 3 1-hour sessions.

q13.value: 500 total sample size from LSU with 5 groups and 100 participants in each group. 100 (age 50 w/ computer v. 50 no computer), 100 ( note-taking medium --verbatim overlap- 50 w/ computer v. 50 no computer), 100 (self-regulating behavior 50 w/ computer v. 50 no computer), 100 (content difficulty 50 w/ computer v. 50 no computer), and 100 (degree of electronic use --  75 w/ computer -- little, moderate, high use-- v. 25 no computer). We would also need 5 teachers to teach the classes.

q14.value: The study will run for a year to measure for retention rates amongst laptop users and nonusers. Also, there will be a total of $7,500 just on participation alone and $450 on teachers. Finally, I would need $1,000 to accommodate for extra fees like tests or obstacles like having to add a different participant because someone else's data was useless.

q15.value: We will post sign up sheets around campus at 10 highly populated areas  on campus every Monday morning. We will ask for an email to fill a survey to see if they meet the requirements. We need all 100 participants for each group to run the study, but not all groups need to be run at exactly the same time, which is why we have a year long duration.

question.value: There are 5 independent variables I plan to use. 1) age - Ranging from 18-50 years old, I want to see if consolidated neural networking allows for an advantage over laptop use in the classroom. 2) content difficulty - I want to see if the actual difficulty of content is to blame for poor retention rates amongst laptop users and/or the duration of the retention interval. 3) Self-regulating behaviors -- Even though the results will be self-reported, an undesired but convenient method, the measurements will be analyzed to determine whether efficacious students are less susceptible to electronic hindrances. 4) note-taking medium - I want to determine if the issue with verbatim overlap is more common in laptop users than in handwritten note takers. 5) amount of electronic device usage - I want to measure how drastically the frequency of electronic use impairs memory.

I will measure AGE to determine if consolidated neural networks/ efficient learning are spared from impaired retention from electronic use, which will be measured by evaluating test scores on the memory test ranging from immediate, 1 week, and 1 month. Next, I will measure CONTENT DIFFICULTY to determine if the harder the information the more likely for lower retention rates depending on electronic use, which will be measured by a test score ranging from immediate - 1 month. Then, I will measure SELF-REGULATING BEHAVIORS, which are gathered through self-reported GPA/ACT/GRE grades, to see if they influence outcomes regarding electronic use. The results from the experiment will be gathered through a memory test ranging from immediate - 1 month. Moreover, I will gather measurements on NOTE_TAKING MEDIUM to determine if the way a participant takes notes (verbatim overlap) depending on laptop use affects memory. The results will be gathered through a series of memory tests ranging from immediate - 1 month. Finally, I will measure the AMOUNT OF ELECTRONIC USE to determine if the frequency of electronic use influences memory test scores. The tests durations will range from immediate - 1 month.
In a post-hoc Tukey test to test for significance among separate groups.

I will use a Between-Subjects ANOVA to determine the measurements between the 1 DV and the 5 I.V. In the ANOVA, I will measure each IV with the 1 D.V. (academic performance). In the electronic usage (little, moderate, high, none) I.V., I plan to fluctuate the amount of usage allowed. After the ANOVA, I will run a post hoc Tukey to determine specific significance between groups.

q20.value: I plan on recording the data for analysis for the post-hoc, but I don't require any transformations.

q21.value: I will use a p<.05 to determine if the one tail ANOVA and post hoc results are significant from the null hypothesis.

q22.value: I will ensure the subject meets criteria for the specified group. Then, I will look over the subjects results to determine if they represent an outlier. Outliers will be included in the analysis; however, they will be marked to allow for analysis without outliers.

q23.value: If a subject fails to complete their test, they will not be included in the data.

q24.value: I do not plan on including exploratory analysis.

attributes.title: Wishful Seeing
attributes.description: This study will test if gender and desirability of an object have an effect on an individual's ability to accurately predict the distance between themselves and that object.

q1.value: Effects of Desirability and Gender on Distance Perception

q2.value: Courtney Patterson, Ashley Morgan, Abigail Duplantis, Abigail Duplantis

q3.value: This study seeks to contribute to research regarding factors that effect visual perception. Much research has been produced discussing how perceived effort, gender, age, and desirability effect a person's ability to accurately evaluate distance. In this study we seek to replicate a study by Emily Balcetis and David Dunning that tests the effect that the desirability of an object has on a person's ability to predict the distance between themselves and the object. We want to expand on this study by then analyzing our data to determine if there is a significant difference between males and females on predicting distance when desirability is manipulated. Desirability will be manipulated by inducing or quenching a participant's thirst. Participants will be randomly assigned to a group that drinks water before the experiment or a group that eats pretzels before the experiment. The participants will then estimate the distance between themselves and a water bottle, the idea being participants who ate pretzels prior will be thirsty and view the water bottle as much more desirable than the participants who had just been given water.

q4.value:
We expect that thirsty participants would rate the bottle of water as more desirable and perceive it as closer than the quenched participants. (directional)

We expect there to be a difference in level of accuracy of perceived distance between male and female participants. (non directional)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This experiment is a between subjects design where participants are randomly assigned to the water or pretzel group.
Measure 1: thirstiness rated on a 7 point likert scale 
Measure: 2: desirability of the water bottle is rated on a 7 point likert scale 
Measure 3: how far the water bottle is away from them reported in inches

q9.value: We will use simple random sampling to assign participants to each group. Groups will have roughly the same amount of males and females.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through offering SONA credits to undergraduate students. Participants will be given 1 credit for attending and participating in the experiment. Students must be at least 18 years of age.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants.

q14.value: A sample size close to 100 will provide enough data to be able to draw significant conclusion from our data.

question.value: We will be manipulating the participants' thirst to test how it manipulates their distance perception. There will be two levels: a thirsty group given pretzels before experimentation and a quenched group given water before experimentation.

We will measure the thirst level of each participant using a 7-point Likert scale and how desirable the participants view a water bottle placed in front of them on a 7 point Likert scale. Then we will measure their perception of distance by showing the a 1 in. line as a reference and asking them to estimate how many inches separate them from the water bottle. (water bottle will be placed 36 in away)

We will find the mean of how many inches away each participant stated the water bottle was from each group: thirsty and quenched. We will then divide the data further and find the mean of how many inches away male participants reported and female participants reported for each group.

We will use two independent t test to analyze the results of our experiment. We used a manipulation check to guarantee that those in the thirsty condition had their last drink at the same time. Another manipulation check guaranteed that those in the pretzel group had more thirst than those in the water group.

q20.value: We do not plan on transforming, centering, recoding the data, or code scheming in this analysis.

q21.value: In determining the statistical significance within our experiment, we will be using a p<.05 criteria. We will use a one tailed t test to analyze the effects of thirsty vs. quenched and a two tailed t test to analyze if there is any significant difference between males and females.

q22.value: Exclusions and outliers will be identified in our analysis. We will not be using any awareness checks.

q23.value: Any participant that does not fully complete their part in the experiment will be excluded.

q24.value: We will look passed our original hypothesis and explore different factors that could influence visual perception.

attributes.title: In-class laptop usage
attributes.description: This study will analyze whether or not laptop use in the classroom benefits students or inhibits their academic performance.

q1.value: Maggie Butler, Cody Capps, Erin Fortier

q2.value: If laptops are used in the classroom, then there will be a negative impact on academic performance.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Maternal Sensitivity to Distress versus Nondistress as Predictor of Dysregulation in Infants
attributes.description:
Sensitive caregiving is characterized as responsiveness to infant cues in a consistent and appropriate manner, and is a widely studied construct in developmental psychology (Ainsworth et al., 1978). Research has shown that early sensitivity is a strong predictor for many different developmental outcomes including cognition, behavior, and language (Marvin, Britner, & Russell, 2016; Cassidy, 2016; Page, Wilhem, Gamble, & Card, 2010).  

To date, and to the best of our knowledge, only two studies address context specific sensitivity and socioemotional outcomes. Leerkes, Blankson and O’Brien (2009) reported that maternal sensitivity to infant distress, but not sensitivity to nondistress, predicted better socio-emotional adjustment. Additionally, Wright, Hill, Sharp, and Pickles (2018) reported that low sensitivity to distress predicted an elevated risk for callous-unemotional (CU) traits. Taken together, these studies suggest that a mother’s responsiveness to their child’s distress may foster their ability to appropriately self-regulate, whereas sensitivity to nondistress is not a sufficient predictor of adaptive socio-emotional regulation. 

This study aims to examine whether maternal sensitivity to distress versus nondistress cues are uniquely associated with infant dysregulation. Dysregulation during infancy involves problems with sleeping, feeding, or negative emotion. Dysregulation early in life forecast problems later in life. For example, Bilgin, et al. (2020) reported that early crying, sleeping, and feeding problems that co-occur and persist are associated with increased odds of attention problems and ADHD diagnoses from childhood to adulthood. These findings underscore the importance of identifying parental behaviors that can support healthy regulation early in life. More specifically, the current study addresses gaps in literature regarding the unique relationship between maternal sensitivity to distress versus nondistress during infancy and later dysregulation.

q1.value: Maternal Sensitivity to Distress Versus Nondistress on Emotional Dysregulation in Children

q2.value: Kylie Shearer, Lee Raby, Jennifer Isenhour, Mindy Brown, sheila crowell, Elisabeth Conradt

q4.value: Maternal sensitivity to distress in infants at 7 months uniquely predicts outcomes on dysregulation at 18 months, but maternal sensitivity to non-distressing play interactions will not.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: This study is part of a broader longitudinal study of 162 women and their biological children. Mother-child dyads were followed from the mother’s third trimester of pregnancy through the child’s third year postnatal. The current study focuses on observations of maternal sensitivity that were collected when children were age 7 months as well as mothers’ reported of children’s dysregulated that were collected when children were age 18 months.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: This study is part of a broader longitudinal study that is ongoing. Although other manuscripts have been published or are in the process of being written, maternal sensitivity during distress and non-distress contexts, and infants’ behavioral outcomes at 18 months have not been examined thus far.

question.value: As described by Lin et al. (2019), recruitment for this study was carried out from January 2016 to October 2018. Research assistants recruited pregnant women who were receiving prenatal care at University of Utah associated OBGYN clinics. Pregnant women were also recruited through flyers, brochures, and social media posts. After responding to the recruitment efforts, interested women completed a screening process. This involved first completing the Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale (DERS) and questions about their age and whether they have experienced any pregnancy complications. Women with high and low scores on the DERS were oversampled, as moderate scores were reported most commonly. There was also oversampling of women who self-identified as belong to a racial or ethnic minority group. Women were considered ineligible from the study if their DERS scores were already adequately represented in the current sample, if they planned to delivery at a hospital that was not part of the research study, or if pregnancy complications occurred. This sample is not representative of the general population, as the study aimed for 33% of the recruited sample to reflect high DERS scores (i.e., emotional dysregulation). The final sample include 162 women. When children were age 7-months, mothers were paid $50 to participate in a laboratory research visit and $25 for completing a set of online questionnaires. When children were 18-months of age, mothers were paid $50 to participate in home visit and an additional $20 for completing a set of questionnaires sent to digitally prior to the home visit.

q13.value: This project will examine data from a subset of 99 participants from the larger cohort. The reason for the reduced sample size is due to the combination of a pending abstract deadline combined with the fact that only 99 participants have fully completed the 18-month assessments at the time of the preregistration.

q15.value: The proposed study has a time constraint and must be completed by the Spring of 2020.

question.value:
Predictor: Mothers’ behaviors were observed at 7 months during the initial 2-minute play episode and the two, 2-minute reunion episodes of the Still-Face Paradigm (SFP). Four raters coded the recorded SFP mother-child interactions using the nine 3-point scales from the Global Ratings of Mother Infant Interaction at 7 Months (Fiori-Cowley, Murray, & Gunning, 1999).

Outcome: The Infant Toddler Social Emotional Assessment (ITSEA) was used to assess social-emotional behavior problems and general competence at 18-months of age (Briggs-Gowan & Carter, 1998). Prior to attending a lab visit, mothers completed an online version of the ITSEA when their child reached the age of 18-months. The current study focused on the dysregulation scale from the ITSEA containing 34 items. Included in the domain are 4 subscales: negative emotionality, sleep, eating, and sensory sensitivity. Items were rated on the following scale: (0) Not true/rarely; (1) Somewhat true/sometimes; (2) Very true/often. Reliability for the dysregulation domain was tested using Cronbach’s alpha (a = .584).

Parental behavior during the play episode and the two reunion episodes was coded using 9, 3-point ratings (Fiori-Cowley, Murray, & Gunning, 1999). Data from the play episodes were available for 106 parents, data from the first reunion were available for 103 parents, and data from the second reunion were available for 81 participants. Ratings for the two reunion episodes were averaged. An exploratory factor analysis (principal axis factoring, oblique rotation) of the nine ratings from the play episode was conducting using data from all participants. The results indicated there were two factors. 

A separate exploratory factor analysis of the nine ratings from the reunion episode also indicated there were two factors. In both analyses, the first factor included responsiveness, acceptance, warmth, non-demandingness, non-intrusive speech, and non-intrusive touch. These ratings were averaged together to form composite measures of “maternal sensitivity” during the play (α = .64) and reunion (α = .87) episodes. 

In both analyses, the second factor included effort, non-remoteness, and bright affect. These ratings were averaged together to form composite measures of “maternal engagement” during the play (α = .67) and reunion (α = .51) episodes. In the full sample, all four variables showed high skew (values between -2.53 and -3.31). In addition, 86% of the cases received the highest possible score for the “maternal engagement” variables during the play and reunion episodes. Given the lack of variability, analyses with these variables were considered exploratory.

Child biological sex, child ethnicity (a binary variable was created to represent ethnicity, White/non-Hispanic or otherwise), family income at the 18-month visit, and maternal education at the 18-month visit will be included as covariates.  

Following descriptives and correlations, hierarchal regression will be used in 2 steps. Step 1 will include maternal sensitivity to distress and sensitivity to nondistress at 7-months on the outcome of dysregulation at 18-months controlling for the overlap between the two variables. Step 2 includes entering covariates.

q20.value: Due to most of the children in the sample identifying as White/non-Hispanic, two categories were created by collapsing ethnic minorities into dichotomous groups including White/non-Hispanic.

q21.value: Statistical significance will be determined using a one-tailed test with a p-value of .05. Any results above a p-value of .05 will be considered not statistically significant.

q22.value: Robustness checks will be conducted on outliers using the 1.5 IQR rule. Their inclusion or exclusion will be determined based on their significance

q23.value: Missing data will be handled using listwise deletion.

q24.value: An exploratory analysis will be run to examine how maternal sensitivity relates to the subscales of dysregulation from the ITSEA which include: negative emotionality, sleep, eating, and sensory sensitivity.

q25.value:
References:

Ainsworth, MDS.; Blehar, MC.; Waters, E.; Wall, S. (1978). Patterns of attachment: A
psychological study of The Strange Situation. Erlbaum; Hillsdale, N.J.: 1978.

Bilgen, A., Baumann, N., Jaekel, J., Breeman, L. D., Bartmann, P., Bauml, J. G., Avram, M., Sorg, C., & Wolke, D. (2020). Early Crying, Sleeping, and Feeding Problems and Trajectories of Attention Problems From Childhood to Adulthood. Child Development, 91(1), e77-e91.

Briggs‐Gowan, M., & Carter, A. (1998). Preliminary acceptability and psychometrics of the infant–toddler social and emotional assessment (ITSEA): A new adult‐report questionnaire. Infant Mental Health Journal, 19(4), 422-445.

Cassidy, J. (2016). The nature of the child’s ties. In J. Cassidy & P. R. Shaver (eds.), Handbook of attachment: Theory, research, and clinical applications (3rd ed., 3-24). New York: Guilford Press.

Leerkes EM, Blankson AN, O’Brien M. (2009) Differential effects of maternal sensitivity to infant distress and nondistress on social-emotional functioning. Child Development. 80:762–775. doi:10.1111/j.1467-8624.2009.01296.x. [PubMed: 19489902]

Leerkes EM. (2011). Maternal sensitivity during distressing tasks: A unique predictor of attachment security. Infant Behavior and Development. 34:443–446. doi:10.1016/j.infbeh.2011.04.006. [PubMed: 21616538]

Marvin, R.S., Britner, P.A., & Russell, B.S. (2016). Normative development: The ontogeny of attachment in childhood. In Cassidy & P.R. Shaver (Eds.), Handbook of attachment: Theory, research, and clinical applications (3rd ed., 273-290). New York: Guilford Press.
 
Page, M., Wilhelm, M.S., Gamble, W.C., Card, N.A. (2010). A comparison of maternal sensitivity and verbal stimulation as unique predictors of infant social-emotional and cognitive development. Infant Behavior and Development. 33, 101-110.
 
Wright, N., Hill, J., Sharp, H., & Pickles, A. (2018). Maternal sensitivity to distress, attachment and the development of callous‐unemotional traits in young children. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, 59(7), 790-800.

attributes.title: Voting for Law and Order in Mexico
attributes.description:
Over the past decade, criminal activity in Latin America has grown exponentially. According
to the 2014 survey of the Latin American Public Opinion Project, one third of Latin Americans
identified crime as their country's main problem. Such violent reality has already had important political consequences across the region. Academic research has revealed the political consequences of criminal violence and victimization experiences in Latin America, mainly focusing on democratic values and participation. Several works found that victims of crime are less likely to trust democratic institutions and support democratic attitudes (Fernandez and Kuenzi, 2010; Blanco, 2013; Carreras, 2013). Moreover, violence has also been shown to increase support for iron fist policies (Holland, 2013; Krause, 2014a; Visconti, 2019). Another set of studies has shown that crime is associated with higher levels of non-electoral forms of participation (Bateson, 2012), while at the same time diminishing electoral participation (Carreras and Trelles,2012; Cantu and Ley, 2017; Ley, 2018).

Overall, prevailing evidence suggests that violence shapes citizens' views on politics, their
interaction with government authorities, and their preferences for security policies (Krause,
2014b; Visconti, 2019; Garcia-Ponce et al., 2019). However, extant works have mainly focused
on mano dura policies , disregarding other policy approaches to crime. Additionally, political
scientists have largely dismissed the processes through which preferences for security policies are shaped, failing to address how voters react to a potentially wide supply of policy approaches. In fact, what we know about how citizens form their electoral preferences amid violence is fairly limited (Ley, 2017).

In this pre-analysis plan, we present a conjoint experiment specifically designed to (a) understand citizens' preferences for security policies; (b) explain how and when different candidate and policy profiles can gain electoral support among voters; and (c) examine the effects of partisanship on preferences for security. In our experiment, respondents are presented with two hypothetical candidates for a municipal election in Mexico that vary along four different attributes, policy proposal for public security, gender, work experience, and political party, and are asked to indicate their preferred candidate. How do citizens make strategic decisions about security policies in violent democracies? What is the role of victimization experiences and fear of crime on voters' electoral and policy preferences? How do voters process candidate profiles amid security concerns? These are some of the questions we seek to answer in this study.

q1.value: Tiago Ventura, Sandra Ley, Francisco Cantu

q2.value:
Looking into popular support for policy proposals to address crime, our work examines different informational short-cuts through which voters process and filter information and, consequently, make decisions. In particular, we group our explanations into three groups: (1) candidate profile and party competence; (2) voter characteristics and social networks; and (3) partisanship.

Candidate Profiles and Party Competence on Security Policies

Our first set of hypotheses focuses on the extent to which some parties and candidates might benefit when campaigning on security as a policy issue. Being aware that political preferences are not merely defined by the demand side, but also by the supply of available choices, we examine how voters value candidates when their campaigns focus on security policy. Building on a growing literature on the credibility of sources (Botero et al., 2015) and voters’ reactions to candidate characteristics (Campbell and Cowley, 2014), we argue that candidates with previous experience on crime control are more likely to be preferred by voters.

Previous professional experience in criminal justice agencies works in two ways. First, as McDermott (2005) shows, candidates’ occupational labels serve as informational shortcuts to infer their competence or qualifications for the office in question. As a result, occupational cues can increase voters’ likelihood to participate and support the candidate that is perceived to have a qualification advantage.

Second, a candidate’s previous experience can also signal her credibility when making campaign promises to tackle crime. How to make candidates to fulfill their campaign promises once in office is one of the most studied questions in the political economy literature (Ferejohn, 1986; Przeworski et al., 1999; Besley, 2006). The main problem for voters is to distinguish an empty promise from a credible policy proposal. For the specific case of public security, candidates’ professional experience serves as a heuristic to voters about how credible is a candidate’s proposal on the topic. We expect then that a candidate with no previous experience on public security pays a credibility cost that makes her proposals unrealistic or naive.

Hypothesis 1. Candidates profiles whose work experience is unrelated to public security are less likely to be selected.

We proceed to measure how partisan cues matter for voters’ evaluation of the candidates. Valence advantages at the party level (Clark, 2009; Calvo and Murillo, 2019; Clarke et al., 2011) and issue ownership (Kaplan et al., 2006) have been shown to function as a critical determinant of vote choice in a variety of contexts. On this matter, previous research indicates how conservative parties tend to have a stronger association with crime control policies and a stronger managerial reputation to deal with crime as their main priority (Holland, 2013; Beckett and Western, 2001). Therefore, we expect conservative parties to receive stronger support in our experiment, independent of more punitive or rehabilitative approach of the proposed policy. Hence, we expect that:

Hypothesis 2. Candidates profiles affiliated with more conservative parties are more likely to be selected.

Overall, in this set of hypotheses, we explore how candidate profiles and parties’ perceived competence relate to the wide variation of security policies we present to the respondents. In other words, our experiment explores interactive effects between the candidates’ professional background and party affiliation with the type of security policy proposal. In this regard, we expect that:

Hypothesis 3. Conservative parties and candidates with professional experience on public security will show greater effects when associated with more punitive policy proposals compared to other more rehabilitative approaches.

Voter Characteristics and Social Networks

Based on the vast literature on social networks and political attitudes (Zuckerman, 2005), we explore how interactions within networks of victims may lead to a different understanding of crime and subsequently affect perceived policy needs and preferences. As Villarreal and Silva (2006) show, information exchanges through networks of individuals experiencing and perceiving crime can have profound attitudinal consequences and lead to a heightened sense of insecurity, which recent works have shown to greatly affect policy preferences (Visconti, 2019; Altamirano et al., 2020; Flores-Macías and Sánchez-Talanquer, 2020).  Therefore, we propose that:

Hypothesis 4. Respondents that have faced crime victimization—either personally or in their immediate social network—are more likely to support punitive policies.

Experiences with violence committed by police forces, however, are likely to have the opposite effect. As comparative evidence shows, from the United States (Desmond et al., 2016) to Brazil (Caldeira, 2002), police violence tends to generate distrust in police forces, as well as reduce crime reporting (Gingerich and Oliveros, 2018). Consequently, we would expect that:

Hypothesis 5. Respondents that have faced police violence—either personally or in their immediate social network—are less likely to support punitive policies.

Continuing with our examination of voter characteristics, we explore an additional individual feature that may increase the probability to vote for a particular public security policy proposal. We focus on voters’ general stances towards the role of the state and its police forces. We propose that:

Hypothesis 6. Respondents supporting tough-on-crime policy approaches will be more likely to choose a candidate proposing death penalty for criminals or the militarization of the police forces.

Partisanship

Following the Michigan School (Campbell et al., 1960), we study the way in which partisan attachments can affect voters’ preferences for candidates. Ideological labels are a useful way in which voters can infer the policy preferences of parties and candidates once in office (Downs, 1957). In principle, the prevalence of ideologies attached to political parties helps voters identify the alternative that most resembles their own view of the world. Our first expectation is that partisanship serves as an information cost-saving device to decide among alternatives on the ballot (Fiorina, 1981). As a result, respondents are more likely to support the candidate from the party that they feel identified with.

At the same time, we consider the consequences of negative partisanship, which we define as an  adverse  affection  towards  a  political  party  (Medeiros  and  Noël,  2014;  Caruana  et  al.,  2015; Samuels and Zucco, 2018). Unlike its positive counterpart, we expect that voters will be less likely to support a candidate from the party they negatively identify with. This occurs because the heuristic that voters receive in this case is about a party supporting policies far away from her political preferences. As a result, even when a candidate proposes a policy closer to what the voter desires, it would be less likely to be selected if it is endorsed by a party that the voter negatively identifies with.

Hypothesis 7. Respondents are more likely to support the candidate from the party that they feel identified with.

Hypothesis 8. Negative partisans are less likely to choose a candidate from the party they dislike.

question.value:
The experiment was added to a national on-line survey in Mexico. Each survey is fielded by Netquest-Vanderbilt, with probabilistic samples draw by the LAPOP team in Vanderbilt from users registered with Netquest.

Respondents are faced with the profiles of two hypothetical candidates for a municipal election. The candidates’ profiles describe four different features: work experience, policy proposal for public security, gender, and political party. See table 1 in the attached pre-analysis plan to a full description of the conjoint's levels.

q7.value: Our experiment uses simple randomization of the conjoint task.  Levels and the features' order are randomized for all the respondents.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Probabilistic sample recruitment by LAPOP-Vanderbilt, based on an agreement with Netquest to use their standing panel.

q12.value: Large sample sizes exceed power requirements for the experiments.

q13.value: Respondents have a limit of one four hour sitting. Expected median LOI under 30 minutes.

question.value: See table 1 of the PAP to a full description of the conjoint task.

Our outcome variable is the marginal effect of each of the candidates’ attributes on vote choice. We measure vote choice using the answers of subjects after observing a pair of hypothetical candidates and responding to the following question “Imagine that the municipal president election is between these two candidates. Which one would you vote for?” We collect the answers for each pair of candidates as well as the randomly generated profile of the candidates that the respondent has to choose from. 

In addition, check the sections 4.3, 4.4 and 4.5 for a complete description of pre-treatment variables we expect to use to detect heterogeneous effects.

We analyze the data using a conjoint analysis. This methodology quantifies the premium or the penalty that each candidate’s attribute has on the voter’s choice (Hainmueller et al., 2014). This methodology has been extensively used in consumer research behavior where, for example, respondents are provided information about certain attributes of a product with different levels for each attribute to participants in an experiment. These attributes and their different levels constitute a profile of a hypothetical product, and participants are asked to make a choice between the multiple products or rate their preferences for each of them. Conjoint experiments allow researchers to examine the weight that each attribute (and its levels) has on the choice or preference of products.

We are interested in two estimands, the Average Marginal Component Effect, and  the Average Component Interactive Effects, both as described and estimated by  Hainmueller et al. (2014). In addition, we intend to use the method in Egami and Imai (2019) also to estimate the interactive effects between some features in our conjoint. 

Section 5 of the attached pre-analysis presents a detailed description of the statistical models and modeling choices we commit to making.

registration_responses.q1: Tiago Ventura, Sandra Ley, Francisco Cantu
registration_responses.q2:
Looking into popular support for policy proposals to address crime, our work examines different informational short-cuts through which voters process and filter information and, consequently, make decisions. In particular, we group our explanations into three groups: (1) candidate profile and party competence; (2) voter characteristics and social networks; and (3) partisanship.

Candidate Profiles and Party Competence on Security Policies

Our first set of hypotheses focuses on the extent to which some parties and candidates might benefit when campaigning on security as a policy issue. Being aware that political preferences are not merely defined by the demand side, but also by the supply of available choices, we examine how voters value candidates when their campaigns focus on security policy. Building on a growing literature on the credibility of sources (Botero et al., 2015) and voters’ reactions to candidate characteristics (Campbell and Cowley, 2014), we argue that candidates with previous experience on crime control are more likely to be preferred by voters.

Previous professional experience in criminal justice agencies works in two ways. First, as McDermott (2005) shows, candidates’ occupational labels serve as informational shortcuts to infer their competence or qualifications for the office in question. As a result, occupational cues can increase voters’ likelihood to participate and support the candidate that is perceived to have a qualification advantage.

Second, a candidate’s previous experience can also signal her credibility when making campaign promises to tackle crime. How to make candidates to fulfill their campaign promises once in office is one of the most studied questions in the political economy literature (Ferejohn, 1986; Przeworski et al., 1999; Besley, 2006). The main problem for voters is to distinguish an empty promise from a credible policy proposal. For the specific case of public security, candidates’ professional experience serves as a heuristic to voters about how credible is a candidate’s proposal on the topic. We expect then that a candidate with no previous experience on public security pays a credibility cost that makes her proposals unrealistic or naive.

Hypothesis 1. Candidates profiles whose work experience is unrelated to public security are less likely to be selected.

We proceed to measure how partisan cues matter for voters’ evaluation of the candidates. Valence advantages at the party level (Clark, 2009; Calvo and Murillo, 2019; Clarke et al., 2011) and issue ownership (Kaplan et al., 2006) have been shown to function as a critical determinant of vote choice in a variety of contexts. On this matter, previous research indicates how conservative parties tend to have a stronger association with crime control policies and a stronger managerial reputation to deal with crime as their main priority (Holland, 2013; Beckett and Western, 2001). Therefore, we expect conservative parties to receive stronger support in our experiment, independent of more punitive or rehabilitative approach of the proposed policy. Hence, we expect that:

Hypothesis 2. Candidates profiles affiliated with more conservative parties are more likely to be selected.

Overall, in this set of hypotheses, we explore how candidate profiles and parties’ perceived competence relate to the wide variation of security policies we present to the respondents. In other words, our experiment explores interactive effects between the candidates’ professional background and party affiliation with the type of security policy proposal. In this regard, we expect that:

Hypothesis 3. Conservative parties and candidates with professional experience on public security will show greater effects when associated with more punitive policy proposals compared to other more rehabilitative approaches.

Voter Characteristics and Social Networks

Based on the vast literature on social networks and political attitudes (Zuckerman, 2005), we explore how interactions within networks of victims may lead to a different understanding of crime and subsequently affect perceived policy needs and preferences. As Villarreal and Silva (2006) show, information exchanges through networks of individuals experiencing and perceiving crime can have profound attitudinal consequences and lead to a heightened sense of insecurity, which recent works have shown to greatly affect policy preferences (Visconti, 2019; Altamirano et al., 2020; Flores-Macías and Sánchez-Talanquer, 2020).  Therefore, we propose that:

Hypothesis 4. Respondents that have faced crime victimization—either personally or in their immediate social network—are more likely to support punitive policies.

Experiences with violence committed by police forces, however, are likely to have the opposite effect. As comparative evidence shows, from the United States (Desmond et al., 2016) to Brazil (Caldeira, 2002), police violence tends to generate distrust in police forces, as well as reduce crime reporting (Gingerich and Oliveros, 2018). Consequently, we would expect that:

Hypothesis 5. Respondents that have faced police violence—either personally or in their immediate social network—are less likely to support punitive policies.

Continuing with our examination of voter characteristics, we explore an additional individual feature that may increase the probability to vote for a particular public security policy proposal. We focus on voters’ general stances towards the role of the state and its police forces. We propose that:

Hypothesis 6. Respondents supporting tough-on-crime policy approaches will be more likely to choose a candidate proposing death penalty for criminals or the militarization of the police forces.

Partisanship

Following the Michigan School (Campbell et al., 1960), we study the way in which partisan attachments can affect voters’ preferences for candidates. Ideological labels are a useful way in which voters can infer the policy preferences of parties and candidates once in office (Downs, 1957). In principle, the prevalence of ideologies attached to political parties helps voters identify the alternative that most resembles their own view of the world. Our first expectation is that partisanship serves as an information cost-saving device to decide among alternatives on the ballot (Fiorina, 1981). As a result, respondents are more likely to support the candidate from the party that they feel identified with.

At the same time, we consider the consequences of negative partisanship, which we define as an  adverse  affection  towards  a  political  party  (Medeiros  and  Noël,  2014;  Caruana  et  al.,  2015; Samuels and Zucco, 2018). Unlike its positive counterpart, we expect that voters will be less likely to support a candidate from the party they negatively identify with. This occurs because the heuristic that voters receive in this case is about a party supporting policies far away from her political preferences. As a result, even when a candidate proposes a policy closer to what the voter desires, it would be less likely to be selected if it is endorsed by a party that the voter negatively identifies with.

Hypothesis 7. Respondents are more likely to support the candidate from the party that they feel identified with.

Hypothesis 8. Negative partisans are less likely to choose a candidate from the party they dislike.
